sn40.11:6.1.pli: (Yathā sakkasuttaṃ tathā ime pañca peyyālā vitthāretabbā.)
sn40.11:6.1.eng: (Tell in full  as in the Discourse With Sakka.)

sn40.11:7.7.eng: The Linked Discourses on Moggallāna are complete.

sn40.2:0.3.eng: A Question About the Second Absorption

sn40.2:1.1.eng: “They speak of this thing called the ‘second absorption’.

sn40.2:1.4.pli: ‘idha bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn40.2:1.4.eng: ‘As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

sn40.2:1.5.eng: This is called the second absorption.’

sn40.2:1.6.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn40.2:1.6.eng: And so … I was entering and remaining in the second absorption.

sn40.2:1.7.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, āvuso, iminā vihārena viharato vitakkasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti.
sn40.2:1.7.eng: While I was in that meditation, perception and focus accompanied by placing the mind beset me.

sn40.2:2.1.pli: Atha kho maṃ, āvuso, bhagavā iddhiyā upasaṅkamitvā etadavoca:
sn40.2:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha came up to me with his psychic power and said,

sn40.2:2.3.pli: Mā, brāhmaṇa, dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ pamādo, dutiye jhāne cittaṃ saṇṭhapehi, dutiye jhāne cittaṃ ekodiṃ karohi, dutiye jhāne cittaṃ samādahā’ti.
sn40.2:2.3.eng: Don’t neglect the second absorption, brahmin! Settle your mind in the second absorption; unify your mind and immerse it in the second absorption.’

sn40.2:2.4.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, aparena samayena vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja vihāsiṃ.
sn40.2:2.4.eng: And so, after some time … I entered and remained in the second absorption.

sn40.2:2.5.pli: Yañhi taṃ, āvuso, sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
sn40.2:2.5.eng: So if anyone should be rightly called

sn40.2:2.6.pli: ‘satthārānuggahito sāvako mahābhiññataṃ patto’ti, mamaṃ taṃ sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
sn40.2:2.6.eng: a disciple who attained to great direct knowledge with help from the Teacher, it’s me.”

sn40.3:0.3.eng: A Question About the Third Absorption

sn40.3:1.1.eng: “They speak of this thing called the ‘third absorption’.

sn40.3:1.4.pli: idha bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca sampajāno sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedeti, yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn40.3:1.4.eng: ‘With the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, “Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.”

sn40.3:1.5.eng: This is called the third absorption.’

sn40.3:1.6.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharāmi sato ca sampajāno sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedemi. Yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn40.3:1.6.eng: And so … I was entering and remaining in the third absorption.

sn40.3:1.7.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, āvuso, iminā vihārena viharato pītisahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti.
sn40.3:1.7.eng: While I was in that meditation, perception and focus accompanied by rapture beset me.

sn40.3:2.1.pli: Atha kho maṃ, āvuso, bhagavā iddhiyā upasaṅkamitvā etadavoca:
sn40.3:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha came up to me with his psychic power and said,

sn40.3:2.3.pli: Mā, brāhmaṇa, tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ pamādo, tatiye jhāne cittaṃ saṇṭhapehi, tatiye jhāne cittaṃ ekodiṃ karohi, tatiye jhāne cittaṃ samādahā’ti.
sn40.3:2.3.eng: Don’t neglect the third absorption, brahmin! Settle your mind in the third absorption; unify your mind and immerse it in the third absorption.’

sn40.3:2.4.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, aparena samayena pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharāmi sato ca sampajāno sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedemi, yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja vihāsiṃ.
sn40.3:2.4.eng: And so, after some time … I entered and remained in the third absorption.

sn40.3:2.5.pli: Yañhi taṃ āvuso sammā vadamāno vadeyya …pe… mahābhiññataṃ patto”ti.
sn40.3:2.5.eng: So if anyone should be rightly called a disciple who attained to great direct knowledge with help from the Teacher, it’s me.”

sn40.4:0.3.eng: A Question About the Fourth Absorption

sn40.4:1.1.eng: “They speak of this thing called the ‘fourth absorption’.

sn40.4:1.4.pli: ‘idha bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn40.4:1.4.eng: ‘It’s when, with the giving up of pleasure and pain and the disappearance of former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

sn40.4:1.5.eng: This is called the fourth absorption.’

sn40.4:1.6.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn40.4:1.6.eng: And so … I was entering and remaining in the fourth absorption.

sn40.4:1.7.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, āvuso, iminā vihārena viharato sukhasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti.
sn40.4:1.7.eng: While I was in that meditation, perception and focus accompanied by pleasure beset me.

sn40.4:2.1.pli: Atha kho maṃ, āvuso, bhagavā iddhiyā upasaṅkamitvā etadavoca:
sn40.4:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha came up to me with his psychic power and said,

sn40.4:2.3.pli: Mā, brāhmaṇa, catutthaṃ jhānaṃ pamādo, catutthe jhāne cittaṃ saṇṭhapehi, catutthe jhāne cittaṃ ekodiṃ karohi, catutthe jhāne cittaṃ samādahā’ti.
sn40.4:2.3.eng: Don’t neglect the fourth absorption, brahmin! Settle your mind in the fourth absorption; unify your mind and immerse it in the fourth absorption.’

sn40.4:2.4.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, aparena samayena sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja vihāsiṃ.
sn40.4:2.4.eng: And so, after some time … I entered and remained in the fourth absorption.

sn40.4:2.5.pli: Yañhi taṃ, āvuso, sammā vadamāno vadeyya …pe… mahābhiññataṃ patto”ti.
sn40.4:2.5.eng: So if anyone should be rightly called a disciple who attained to great direct knowledge with help from the Teacher, it’s me.”

sn40.5:0.3.eng: A Question About the Dimension of Infinite Space

sn40.5:1.1.eng: “They speak of this thing called the ‘dimension of infinite space’.

sn40.5:1.2.eng: What is the dimension of infinite space?

sn40.5:1.4.pli: ‘idha bhikkhu sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ananto ākāsoti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn40.5:1.4.eng: ‘It’s when a mendicant—going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity—aware that “space is infinite”, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.

sn40.5:1.5.eng: This is called the dimension of infinite space.’

sn40.5:1.6.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ananto ākāsoti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn40.5:1.6.eng: And so … I was entering and remaining in the dimension of infinite space.

sn40.5:1.7.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, āvuso, iminā vihārena viharato rūpasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti.
sn40.5:1.7.eng: While I was in that meditation, perception and focus accompanied by forms beset me.

sn40.5:2.1.pli: Atha kho maṃ, āvuso, bhagavā iddhiyā upasaṅkamitvā etadavoca:
sn40.5:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha came up to me with his psychic power and said,

sn40.5:2.3.pli: Mā, brāhmaṇa, ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ pamādo, ākāsānañcāyatane cittaṃ saṇṭhapehi, ākāsānañcāyatane cittaṃ ekodiṃ karohi, ākāsānañcāyatane cittaṃ samādahā’ti.
sn40.5:2.3.eng: Don’t neglect the dimension of infinite space, brahmin! Settle your mind in the dimension of infinite space; unify your mind and immerse it in the dimension of infinite space.’

sn40.5:2.4.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, aparena samayena sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ananto ākāsoti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja vihāsiṃ.
sn40.5:2.4.eng: And so, after some time … I entered and remained in the dimension of infinite space.

sn40.5:2.5.pli: Yañhi taṃ, āvuso, sammā vadamāno vadeyya …pe… mahābhiññataṃ patto”ti.
sn40.5:2.5.eng: So if anyone should be rightly called a disciple who attained to great direct knowledge with help from the Teacher, it’s me.”

sn40.6:0.3.eng: A Question About the Dimension of Infinite Consciousness

sn40.6:1.1.eng: “They speak of this thing called the ‘dimension of infinite consciousness’.

sn40.6:1.2.eng: What is the dimension of infinite consciousness?

sn40.6:1.4.pli: ‘idha bhikkhu sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma anantaṃ viññāṇanti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn40.6:1.4.eng: ‘It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that “consciousness is infinite”, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

sn40.6:1.5.eng: This is called the dimension of infinite consciousness.’

sn40.6:1.6.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma anantaṃ viññāṇanti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn40.6:1.6.eng: And so … I was entering and remaining in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

sn40.6:1.7.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, āvuso, iminā vihārena viharato ākāsānañcāyatanasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti.
sn40.6:1.7.eng: While I was in that meditation, perception and focus accompanied by the dimension of infinite space beset me.

sn40.6:2.1.pli: Atha kho maṃ, āvuso, bhagavā iddhiyā upasaṅkamitvā etadavoca:
sn40.6:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha came up to me with his psychic power and said,

sn40.6:2.3.pli: Mā, brāhmaṇa, viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ pamādo, viññāṇañcāyatane cittaṃ saṇṭhapehi, viññāṇañcāyatane cittaṃ ekodiṃ karohi, viññāṇañcāyatane cittaṃ samādahā’ti.
sn40.6:2.3.eng: Don’t neglect the dimension of infinite consciousness, brahmin! Settle your mind in the dimension of infinite consciousness; unify your mind and immerse it in the dimension of infinite consciousness.’

sn40.6:2.4.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, aparena samayena sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma anantaṃ viññāṇanti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja vihāsiṃ.
sn40.6:2.4.eng: And so, after some time … I entered and remained in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

sn40.6:2.5.pli: Yañhi taṃ, āvuso, sammā vadamāno vadeyya …pe… mahābhiññataṃ patto”ti.
sn40.6:2.5.eng: So if anyone should be rightly called a disciple who attained to great direct knowledge with help from the Teacher, it’s me.”

sn40.7:0.3.eng: A Question About the Dimension of Nothingness

sn40.7:1.1.eng: “They speak of this thing called the ‘dimension of nothingness’.

sn40.7:1.2.eng: What is the dimension of nothingness?

sn40.7:1.4.pli: ‘idha bhikkhu sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma natthi kiñcīti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn40.7:1.4.eng: ‘It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that “there is nothing at all”, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.

sn40.7:1.5.eng: This is called the dimension of nothingness.’

sn40.7:1.6.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma natthi kiñcīti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn40.7:1.6.eng: And so … I was entering and remaining in the dimension of nothingness.

sn40.7:1.7.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, āvuso, iminā vihārena viharato viññāṇañcāyatanasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti.
sn40.7:1.7.eng: While I was in that meditation, perception and focus accompanied by the dimension of infinite consciousness beset me.

sn40.7:2.1.pli: Atha kho maṃ, āvuso, bhagavā iddhiyā upasaṅkamitvā etadavoca:
sn40.7:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha came up to me with his psychic power and said,

sn40.7:2.3.pli: Mā, brāhmaṇa, ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ pamādo, ākiñcaññāyatane cittaṃ saṇṭhapehi, ākiñcaññāyatane cittaṃ ekodiṃ karohi, ākiñcaññāyatane cittaṃ samādahā’ti.
sn40.7:2.3.eng: Don’t neglect the dimension of nothingness, brahmin! Settle your mind in the dimension of nothingness; unify your mind and immerse it in the dimension of nothingness.’

sn40.7:2.4.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, aparena samayena sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma natthi kiñcīti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja vihāsiṃ.
sn40.7:2.4.eng: And so, after some time … I entered and remained in the dimension of nothingness.

sn40.7:2.5.pli: Yañhi taṃ, āvuso, sammā vadamāno vadeyya …pe… mahābhiññataṃ patto”ti.
sn40.7:2.5.eng: So if anyone should be rightly called a disciple who attained to great direct knowledge with help from the Teacher, it’s me.”

sn40.8:0.3.eng: A Question About the Dimension of Neither Perception Nor Non-Perception

sn40.8:1.1.eng: “They speak of this thing called the ‘dimension of neither perception nor non-perception’.

sn40.8:1.2.eng: What is the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception?

sn40.8:1.4.pli: ‘idha bhikkhu sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn40.8:1.4.eng: ‘It’s when a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, enters and remains in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

sn40.8:1.5.eng: This is called the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’

sn40.8:1.6.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn40.8:1.6.eng: And so … I was entering and remaining in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

sn40.8:1.7.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, āvuso, iminā vihārena viharato ākiñcaññāyatanasahagatā saññāmanasikārā samudācaranti.
sn40.8:1.7.eng: While I was in that meditation, perception and focus accompanied by the dimension of nothingness beset me.

sn40.8:2.1.pli: Atha kho maṃ, āvuso, bhagavā iddhiyā upasaṅkamitvā etadavoca:
sn40.8:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha came up to me with his psychic power and said,

sn40.8:2.3.pli: Mā, brāhmaṇa, nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ pamādo, nevasaññānāsaññāyatane cittaṃ saṇṭhapehi, nevasaññānāsaññāyatane cittaṃ ekodiṃ karohi, nevasaññānāsaññāyatane cittaṃ samādahā’ti.
sn40.8:2.3.eng: Don’t neglect the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, brahmin! Settle your mind in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception; unify your mind and immerse it in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’

sn40.8:2.4.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, aparena samayena sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja vihāsiṃ.
sn40.8:2.4.eng: And so, after some time … I entered and remained in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

sn40.8:2.5.pli: Yañhi taṃ, āvuso, sammā vadamāno vadeyya …pe… mahābhiññataṃ patto”ti.
sn40.8:2.5.eng: So if anyone should be rightly called a disciple who attained to great direct knowledge with help from the Teacher, it’s me.”

sn40.9:1.1.eng: “They speak of this thing called the ‘signless immersion of the heart’.

sn40.9:1.2.eng: What is the signless immersion of the heart?

sn40.9:1.4.pli: ‘idha bhikkhu sabbanimittānaṃ amanasikārā animittaṃ cetosamādhiṃ upasampajja viharati.
sn40.9:1.4.eng: ‘It’s when a mendicant, not focusing on any signs, enters and remains in the signless immersion of the heart.

sn40.9:1.5.eng: This is called the signless immersion of the heart.’

sn40.9:1.6.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, sabbanimittānaṃ amanasikārā animittaṃ cetosamādhiṃ upasampajja viharāmi.
sn40.9:1.6.eng: And so … I was entering and remaining in the signless immersion of the heart.

sn40.9:1.7.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, āvuso, iminā vihārena viharato nimittānusāri viññāṇaṃ hoti.
sn40.9:1.7.eng: While I was in that meditation, my consciousness followed after signs.

sn40.9:2.1.pli: Atha kho maṃ, āvuso, bhagavā iddhiyā upasaṅkamitvā etadavoca:
sn40.9:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha came up to me with his psychic power and said,

sn40.9:2.3.pli: Mā, brāhmaṇa, animittaṃ cetosamādhiṃ pamādo, animitte cetosamādhismiṃ cittaṃ saṇṭhapehi, animitte cetosamādhismiṃ cittaṃ ekodiṃ karohi, animitte cetosamādhismiṃ cittaṃ samādahā’ti.
sn40.9:2.3.eng: Don’t neglect the signless immersion of the heart, brahmin! Settle your mind in the signless immersion of the heart; unify your mind and immerse it in the signless immersion of the heart.’

sn40.9:2.4.pli: So khvāhaṃ, āvuso, aparena samayena sabbanimittānaṃ amanasikārā animittaṃ cetosamādhiṃ upasampajja vihāsiṃ.
sn40.9:2.4.eng: And so, after some time … I entered and remained in the signless immersion of the heart.

sn40.9:2.5.pli: Yañhi taṃ, āvuso, sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
sn40.9:2.5.eng: So if anyone should be rightly called

sn40.9:2.6.pli: ‘satthārānuggahito sāvako mahābhiññataṃ patto’ti, mamaṃ taṃ sammā vadamāno vadeyya:
sn40.9:2.6.eng: a disciple who attained to great direct knowledge with help from the Teacher, it’s me.”

sn41.1:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ sambahulā therā bhikkhū macchikāsaṇḍe viharanti ambāṭakavane.
sn41.1:1.1.eng: At one time several senior mendicants were staying near Macchikāsaṇḍa in the Wild Mango Grove.

sn41.1:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulānaṃ therānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantānaṃ maṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnānaṃ sannipatitānaṃ ayamantarākathā udapādi:
sn41.1:1.2.eng: Now at that time, after the meal, on return from almsround, several senior mendicants sat together in the pavilion and this discussion came up among them:

sn41.1:1.3.pli: “‘saṃyojanan’ti vā, āvuso, ‘saṃyojaniyā dhammā’ti vā ime dhammā nānatthā nānābyañjanā udāhu ekatthā byañjanameva nānan”ti?
sn41.1:1.3.eng: “Reverends, the ‘fetter’ and the ‘things that tighten fetters’: do these things differ in both meaning and phrasing? Or do they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing?”

sn41.1:1.4.pli: Tatrekaccehi therehi bhikkhūhi evaṃ byākataṃ hoti:
sn41.1:1.4.eng: Some senior mendicants answered like this:

sn41.1:1.5.pli: “‘saṃyojanan’ti vā, āvuso, ‘saṃyojaniyā dhammā’ti vā ime dhammā nānatthā ceva nānābyañjanā cā”ti.
sn41.1:1.5.eng: “Reverends, the ‘fetter’ and the ‘things that tighten fetters’: these things differ in both meaning and phrasing.”

sn41.1:1.6.pli: Ekaccehi therehi bhikkhūhi evaṃ byākataṃ hoti:
sn41.1:1.6.eng: But some senior mendicants answered like this:

sn41.1:1.7.pli: “‘saṃyojanan’ti vā, āvuso, ‘saṃyojaniyā dhammā’ti vā ime dhammā ekatthā byañjanameva nānan”ti.
sn41.1:1.7.eng: “Reverends, the ‘fetter’ and the ‘things that tighten fetters’ mean the same thing; they differ only in the phrasing.”

sn41.1:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena citto gahapati migapathakaṃ anuppatto hoti kenacideva karaṇīyena.
sn41.1:2.1.eng: Now at that time the householder Citta had arrived at Migapathaka on some business.

sn41.1:2.2.pli: Assosi kho citto gahapati sambahulānaṃ kira therānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantānaṃ maṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnānaṃ sannipatitānaṃ ayamantarākathā udapādi:
sn41.1:2.2.eng: He heard about what those senior mendicants were discussing.

sn41.1:2.3.pli: “‘saṃyojanan’ti vā, āvuso, ‘saṃyojaniyā dhammā’ti vā ime dhammā nānatthā nānābyañjanā udāhu ekatthā byañjanameva nānan”ti?

sn41.1:2.5.pli: “‘saṃyojanan’ti vā, āvuso, ‘saṃyojaniyā dhammā’ti vā ime dhammā nānatthā ceva nānābyañjanā cā”ti.

sn41.1:2.7.pli: “‘saṃyojanan’ti vā, āvuso, ‘saṃyojaniyā dhammā’ti vā ime dhammā ekatthā byañjanameva nānan”ti.

sn41.1:3.1.pli: Atha kho citto gahapati yena therā bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā there bhikkhū abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho citto gahapati there bhikkhū etadavoca:
sn41.1:3.1.eng: So he went up to them, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to them,

sn41.1:3.2.pli: “sutaṃ metaṃ, bhante, sambahulānaṃ kira therānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantānaṃ maṇḍalamāḷe sannisinnānaṃ sannipatitānaṃ ayamantarākathā udapādi:
sn41.1:3.2.eng: “Sirs, I heard that you were discussing whether the ‘fetter’ and the ‘things that tighten fetters’ differ in both meaning and phrasing, or whether they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing.”

sn41.1:3.3.pli: ‘saṃyojanan’ti vā, āvuso, ‘saṃyojaniyā dhammā’ti vā ime dhammā nānatthā nānābyañjanā udāhu ekatthā byañjanameva nānan”ti?

sn41.1:3.5.pli: “‘saṃyojanan’ti vā, āvuso, ‘saṃyojaniyā dhammā’ti vā ime dhammā nānatthā ceva nānābyañjanā cā”ti.

sn41.1:3.6.pli: Ekaccehi therehi bhikkhūhi evaṃ byākataṃ “‘saṃyojanan’ti vā, āvuso, ‘saṃyojaniyā dhammā’ti vā ime dhammā ekatthā byañjanameva nānan”ti.

sn41.1:4.1.pli: “‘Saṃyojanan’ti vā, bhante, ‘saṃyojaniyā dhammā’ti vā ime dhammā nānatthā ceva nānābyañjanā ca.
sn41.1:4.1.eng: “Sirs, the ‘fetter’ and the ‘things that tighten fetters’: these things differ in both meaning and phrasing.

sn41.1:4.2.pli: Tena hi, bhante, upamaṃ vo karissāmi.
sn41.1:4.2.eng: Well then, sirs, I shall give you a simile.

sn41.1:4.3.pli: Upamāyapidhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṃ ājānanti.
sn41.1:4.3.eng: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.

sn41.1:4.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, kāḷo ca balībaddo odāto ca balībaddo ekena dāmena vā yottena vā saṃyuttā assu.
sn41.1:4.4.eng: Suppose there was a black ox and a white ox yoked by a single harness or yoke.

sn41.1:4.5.eng: Would it be right to say that

sn41.1:4.6.pli: ‘kāḷo balībaddo odātassa balībaddassa saṃyojanaṃ, odāto balībaddo kāḷassa balībaddassa saṃyojanan’ti, sammā nu kho so vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?
sn41.1:4.6.eng: the black ox is the yoke of the white ox, or the white ox is the yoke of the black ox?”

sn41.1:4.8.pli: Na kho, gahapati, kāḷo balībaddo odātassa balībaddassa saṃyojanaṃ, napi odāto balībaddo kāḷassa balībaddassa saṃyojanaṃ;
sn41.1:4.8.eng: The black ox is not the yoke of the white ox, nor is the white ox the yoke of the black ox.

sn41.1:4.9.pli: yena kho te ekena dāmena vā yottena vā saṃyuttā taṃ tattha saṃyojanan”ti.
sn41.1:4.9.eng: The yoke there is the single harness or yoke that they’re yoked by.”

sn41.1:4.10.pli: “Evameva kho, bhante, na cakkhu rūpānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, na rūpā cakkhussa saṃyojanaṃ;
sn41.1:4.10.eng: “In the same way, the eye is not the fetter of sights, nor are sights the fetter of the eye.

sn41.1:4.11.pli: yañca tattha tadubhayaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo taṃ tattha saṃyojanaṃ.
sn41.1:4.11.eng: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.

sn41.1:4.15.pli: na kāyo phoṭṭhabbānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, na phoṭṭhabbā kāyassa saṃyojanaṃ;

sn41.1:4.16.pli: yañca tattha tadubhayaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo taṃ tattha saṃyojanaṃ.

sn41.1:4.17.pli: Na mano dhammānaṃ saṃyojanaṃ, na dhammā manassa saṃyojanaṃ;
sn41.1:4.17.eng: mind is not the fetter of ideas, nor are ideas the fetter of the mind.

sn41.1:4.18.pli: yañca tattha tadubhayaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandarāgo taṃ tattha saṃyojanan”ti.
sn41.1:4.18.eng: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.”

sn41.1:4.20.pli: yassa te gambhīre buddhavacane paññācakkhu kamatī”ti.
sn41.1:4.20.eng: to traverse the Buddha’s deep teachings with the eye of wisdom.”

sn41.10:1.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena citto gahapati ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
sn41.10:1.1.eng: Now at that time the householder Citta was sick, suffering, gravely ill.

sn41.10:1.2.pli: Atha kho sambahulā ārāmadevatā vanadevatā rukkhadevatā osadhitiṇavanappatīsu adhivatthā devatā saṅgamma samāgamma cittaṃ gahapatiṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn41.10:1.2.eng: Then several deities of the parks, forests, trees, and those who haunt the herbs, grass, and big trees came together and said to Citta,

sn41.10:1.3.eng: “Householder, make a wish to become a wheel-turning monarch in the future!”

sn41.10:2.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, citto gahapati tā ārāmadevatā vanadevatā rukkhadevatā osadhitiṇavanappatīsu adhivatthā devatā etadavoca:
sn41.10:2.1.eng: When they said this, Citta said to them,

sn41.10:2.2.pli: “tampi aniccaṃ, tampi addhuvaṃ, tampi pahāya gamanīyan”ti.
sn41.10:2.2.eng: “That too is impermanent! That too will pass! That too will be left behind!”

sn41.10:2.3.pli: Evaṃ vutte, cittassa gahapatino mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā cittaṃ gahapatiṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn41.10:2.3.eng: When he said this, his friends and colleagues, relatives and kin said,

sn41.10:2.5.pli: “Kiṃ tāhaṃ vadāmi yaṃ maṃ tumhe evaṃ vadetha:
sn41.10:2.5.eng: “What have I said that makes you say that?”

sn41.10:2.8.pli: ‘tampi aniccaṃ, tampi addhuvaṃ, tampi pahāya gamanīyan’”ti.
sn41.10:2.8.eng: ‘That too is impermanent! That too will pass! That too will be left behind!’”

sn41.10:2.9.pli: “Tathā hi pana maṃ ārāmadevatā vanadevatā rukkhadevatā osadhitiṇavanappatīsu adhivatthā devatā evamāhaṃsu:
sn41.10:2.9.eng: “Oh, well, that’s because the deities of the parks, forests, trees, and those who haunt the herbs, grass, and big trees said to me:

sn41.10:2.10.eng: ‘Householder, make a wish to become a wheel-turning monarch in the future!’

sn41.10:2.12.eng: ‘That too is impermanent! That too will pass! That too will be left behind!’”

sn41.10:2.13.pli: “Kiṃ pana tā, ayyaputta, ārāmadevatā vanadevatā rukkhadevatā osadhitiṇavanappatīsu adhivatthā devatā atthavasaṃ sampassamānā evamāhaṃsu:
sn41.10:2.13.eng: “But what reason do they see for saying that to you?”

sn41.10:2.15.pli: “Tāsaṃ kho ārāmadevatānaṃ vanadevatānaṃ rukkhadevatānaṃ osadhitiṇavanappatīsu adhivatthānaṃ devatānaṃ evaṃ hoti:

sn41.10:2.16.eng: ‘This householder Citta is ethical, of good character.

sn41.10:2.17.eng: If he makes a wish to

sn41.10:2.18.pli: anāgatamaddhānaṃ rājā assaṃ cakkavattī’ti, ‘tassa kho ayaṃ ijjhissati, sīlavato cetopaṇidhi visuddhattā dhammiko dhammikaṃ phalaṃ anupassatī’ti.
sn41.10:2.18.eng: become a wheel-turning monarch in the future, his heart’s wish will succeed because of the purity of his ethics. And then as a proper, principled king he will provide proper spirit-offerings.’

sn41.10:2.19.pli: Imaṃ kho tā ārāmadevatā vanadevatā rukkhadevatā osadhitiṇavanappatīsu adhivatthā devatā atthavasaṃ sampassamānā evamāhaṃsu:
sn41.10:2.19.eng: That’s the reason they see for saying to me:

sn41.10:2.20.eng: ‘Householder, make a wish to become a wheel-turning monarch in the future!’

sn41.10:2.22.pli: ‘tampi aniccaṃ, tampi addhuvaṃ, tampi pahāya gamanīyan’”ti.
sn41.10:2.22.eng: ‘That too is impermanent! That too will pass! That too will be left behind!’”

sn41.10:3.3.eng: We will have experiential confidence in the Buddha:

sn41.10:3.4.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
sn41.10:3.4.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

sn41.10:3.5.eng: We will have experiential confidence in the teaching:

sn41.10:3.6.pli: ‘svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī’ti.
sn41.10:3.6.eng: ‘The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.’

sn41.10:3.7.eng: We will have experiential confidence in the Saṅgha:

sn41.10:3.8.pli: ‘suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, ujuppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, ñāyappaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, sāmīcippaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, yadidaṃ cattāri purisayugāni aṭṭha purisapuggalā esa bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho āhuneyyo pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā’ti.
sn41.10:3.8.eng: ‘The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is practicing the way that’s good, direct, systematic, and proper. It consists of the four pairs, the eight individual persons. This is the Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples that is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.’

sn41.10:3.9.pli: Yaṃ kho pana kiñci kule deyyadhammaṃ sabbaṃ taṃ appaṭivibhattaṃ bhavissati sīlavantehi kalyāṇadhammehīti evañhi vo sikkhitabban”ti.
sn41.10:3.9.eng: And we will share without reservation all the gifts available to give in our family with those who are ethical and of good character.”

sn41.10:3.10.pli: Atha kho citto gahapati mittāmacce ñātisālohite buddhe ca dhamme ca saṅghe ca cāge ca samādapetvā kālamakāsīti.
sn41.10:3.10.eng: Then, after Citta had encouraged his friends and colleagues, relatives and kin in the Buddha, the teaching, the Saṅgha, and generosity, he passed away.

sn41.10:4.5.eng: The Linked Discourses on Citta the Householder are complete.
